intro: Galium syreitschikowii, commonly known as the Sierra galingale, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, sprawling stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks. Its botanical features make it a notable species in ecological studies and botanical gardens.
